intervention_description:
training to identify fake websites; detailed steps that can be taken in order to implement security practices; three kinds of fear appeal messages (basic fear appeal, two-sided fear appeal, graphic fear appeal); two kinds of training (CDT present (Component Display Theory applied (training is learner-driven along two dimensions [content and performance] and provides primary and secondary presentation forms)); CDT non-present); CDT-centered tutorial provided avenues for rules, examples, recall, practice and control which was facilitated by stating objectives (making the training menu-based, with interactive modules, hyperlinks, interactive practice examples
and quizzes.); self-efficacy was measured pre- and post-test

title: Serious Games for Cyber Security Education
Serious Games for Cyber Security Education
intervention_description: The game is designed to randomly generate worms associate with URLs. The small fish (the game player) is presented a worm each time associated with a different URL. The URL can b either phishing or legitimate. When the user moves from the beginning to the end of the game, the complexity of URLs is dramatically increased. This helps the user to gain the conceptual knowledge of identifying URLs. Therefore, self-efficacy of preventing from phishing attacks will be addressed in the game design.
intervention_description_new: game to identify phishing URLs: fish is presented an URL-worm (either phishing or legitimate) with increasing URL-complexity

intervention_description:
intervention consisting of randomly presented pairs of cyber privacy awareness messages; relied on the literature around perceived trustworthiness and
uncertainty of control (as part of privacy concern) to craft cyber privacy awareness messages
that, I submit, are reasonably calculated to either increase or decrease an individual’s level of
perceived trustworthiness, on the one hand, and to either increase or decrease their perception of
uncertainty on the other; objective of each cyber privacy awareness message was to present the participant-Online User
with scenarios drafted such that they could easily imagine that “this could be me.”; The full text of the cyber privacy awareness message corresponding to each
condition is presented in Table 2; UCOI conditions, set forth in Table 3
intervention_description_new: exposure to cyber privacy risk awareness messages: levels of perceived trustworthiness (increased vs. decreased) and levels perception of uncertainty (increased vs. decreased)

title: Addressing Gender Gaps in Teens' Cybersecurity Engagement and Self-Efficacy
notes: survey was administered 3 times (1 baseline before the camp, 1 after the workshops, 1 after the cyberdefense simulation): alpha 0.968, 0.964, 0.974
intervention_description: On the first four days of the camp, the students attended workshops in which they participated in hands-on cybersecurity-related activities.­ Activities included lessons on Internet research, Internet safety, virtualization, HTML, systems administration, networking, computer hygiene, and Web development and hosting. Many of the lessons, particularly those on HTML and Web design, required the participants to create a website for a customer-facing e-business. Website development was tied in throughout the workshops; for example, one of the lessons on systems administration included applications on the campers’ websites. On the final afternoon of the camp, the students participated in a cyberdefense simulation. They formed groups of two (with one group of three) and “merged” their companies into a corporation. The teams then worked collaboratively to complete various tasks related to their website, such as monitoring and checking questionable website traffic, performing administration and auditing tasks, detecting a live cyberattack, and recovering from the attack.
intervention_description_new: camp to learn cybersecurity-related activities for websites: workshop (build website) and simulation (cybersecurity tasks)

title: “Everything under control?”: Privacy control salience influences both critical processing and perceived persuasiveness of targeted advertising among adolescents
journal_book_conf: Cyberpsychology Journal of Psychosocial Research on Cyberspace
intervention_description: Every participant saw the same blurred profile page with the targeted ad, but in line with our three conditions, the screenshots did differ in their degree of privacy control salience; The low privacy control salience condition displayed the newsfeed with only the ‘Sneaky Shoe’ targeted ad, without any privacy control element. The moderate privacy control salience condition portrayed the exact same newsfeed and ad, but this time we included a dropdown privacy control menu next to the sponsored post, allowing the user to have more control over the displayed ads (e.g., option to learn more about the targeting process, option to hide or report the ad, etc.). This menu should increase privacy control salience. Finally, the high privacy control salience condition was similar to the former one, but on top of the dropdown menu, we included an in-feed privacy notification of Facebook as well, which informs users of additional ways to secure one’s personal profile (with a button to get started).
intervention_description_new: exposure to Facebook's news feeds:  low privacy control salience (targeted ad) vs. moderate privacy control salience (drop-down menu to control ad) vs. high privacy control salience (drop-down menu and in-feed privacy notification with button)
